revisionDesc.change: Correction by the text identification on ff. 84v-86r

listBibl.head: Selected bibliography:
listBibl.bibl: Finch, Chauncey E. "Three Textual Notes," Illinois Classical Studies 3 (1978): 269-272 esp. 269-272
Laistner, M. L. W., and H. H. King. A Hand-List of Bede Manuscripts. Itaca: Cornell university press, 1943.

Mostert, Marco. The Library of Fleury. A Provisional List of Manuscripts. Hilversum: Verloren, 1989.according to Mostert the manuscript consists of five distinctive parts: ff- 1-16, 17-86, 87-124, 125-164 164-179, whereby the first three (ff. 1-124) are contemporary and homogenous (citing also Munk Olsen). The script shows insular influence (Pellegrin, Les manuscrits classiques 2.1, pp. 155-158). Pellegrin: France, Carey, Jones: Fleury; provenance prob. Fleury ff. 125-164 only prov. prob. Fleury s. X; ff. 165-179: s. X/XI prov. prob. Fleury.
Viré, Ghislaine. ‘La transmission du De astronomia d’Hygin jusqu’au XIIIe siècle’. Revue d’histoire des textes 11 (1981): 159–276.
Viré, Ghislaine. ‘Le Texte Du “De Astronomia” d’Hygin: Question de Méthode’. Latomus 51 (1992): 843–56.

msItem.incipit: Est domus in terris set uiuit sempe in undis
msItem.bibl: Chauncey E. Finch, "Three Textual Notes," Illinois Classical Studies 3 (1978) 269-272.

msItem.incipit: Est enim racio qualiter terminus paschalis inueniri possit. martius habet relulares XXXVI aprilis XXXV si uis inuenire terminum in martium

msItem.rubric: Incipit compotum grecorum anni circuli qualiter calculare debeas
msItem.incipit: Ianuarius augustus et december IIII Nonas habent
msItem.explicit: Si uis inuenire quota feria sir ipse terminus pachalis
msItem.bibl: Borst, Der karolingische Reichskalender und seine Überlieferung bis ins 12. Jahrhundert. Teil 1, pp. 403.

msItem.author: Bede
msItem.title: De natura rerum (ch. 14-17)
msItem.incipit: Sunt autem sui cuique planetarum circuli quos greci hapsides in stellis uocant
msItem.explicit: Signa XII uel a causis annalibus uel a gentilium fabulis nomina sumpserunt.

msItem.note: Excerpts from the Aratus Latinus and the Revised Aratus Latinus as addition to Bede's DNR on the zodiacal signs their mythological origin and number of stars.
msItem.incipit: quas ideo strictim ac breuiter subter notare curauimus
msItem.explicit: sub mammis , in sinistro lumbo I.
msItem.note: Pellegrin noted that the texts on ff. 84v-86r are present also in Leiden, UB, VLO 15, ff. 188-190.

msItem.title: De sideribus
msItem.author: Ps. Priscianus
msItem.note: Added probably in the 11th century with musical neumes.

msItem.rubric: In dei nomine incipiunt pauca de ratione conputandi secundum solem et lunam me legat annales uult qui cognoscere ciclos tempora qui uaria qui simul astra poli
msItem.incipit: Sciendum nobis quo modo sol in principalibus linguis uocatur

supportDesc.collation: Quire marks in roman numerlas on the last verso of quires on fols. 8v (I), 16v (II), 24v (IIII), 32v (V), 40v (VI), 48v (VII), 54v (VIII), 62v (VIIII), 70v (X), 78v (XI), 86v (XII), 94v (XIII), 102v (XIIII), 110v and 118v probably cut out with the lower margin (XV? and XVI?), 124v (XVII);

history.origin: Viré (1981) suggested that the manuscript was written in Northern France, possibly in Auxerre (following a suggestion by B. Bischoff). Laistner and Beeson considered it a product of Fleury. Pellegrin argued for a French origin; script exhibiting insular influence.
history.provenance: By the 16 th c. the manuscript was probably in the Abbey of Fleury-sur-Loire as it matches the succinct title (Liber Bedae presbyteri de natura rerum) of No 254 in the catalogue of 1552.
Ownership note by Pierre Daniel of Orleans (d. 1603) on f. 1r; according to Pellegrini also his marginal notes in the manuscript.

msItem.author: Aethicus Ister
msItem.title: Cosmographia
msItem.rubric: Incipit liber Aethici philosophico editus oraculo a Hieronimo presbitero translatus in latinum ex cosmografia mundi scriptura edicta aethici philosophi cosmographi

msItem.note: Four glossaries of Greek and Latin medical terms.
msItem.incipit: De decem specibus medicamentorum; haec sunt de animalibus terennis
msItem.bibl: Goetz, Corpus glossarum latinorum 3 (Leipzig, 1892), pp. xxxii-xxxiii.

supportDesc.collation: The text of Aethicus' Cosmographia is in five regular quaternios (125-132, 133-140, 141-148, 149-156, 157-164), sewing strings visible in the middle of quires, with two surviving quire marks at the bottom of the last verso in capital letters: f. 132v (A) and f. 164v (E). The Hermeneumata take one quaternio (ff. 165-172) and one ternio (ff. 173-178).
